markdownRemark.html:
Defining Notation for Determining Causality

  • As an example, let's say we want to know if providing schools with laptops will cause their students to receive better SAT scores

    • The control group will include schools without laptops
    • The treatment group will include schools with laptops

  • Each variable has the following notation:

    • iii represents a given school

    • ttt represents the group that school iii falls into

      • t=0t=0t=0 if the ithi^{th}ith school isn't provided laptops
      • t=1t=1t=1 if the ithi^{th}ith school is provided laptops

    • YYY represents the average SAT scores for school iii

      • Y0Y^{0}Y0 are the average SAT scores for the control group
      • Y1Y^{1}Y1 are the average SAT scores for the treatment group

Illustrating ATEATEATE with SAT Scores

  • Theoretically, let's just imagine we're able to somehow capture data for each ithi^{th}ith school in both a treatment and control group
  • Again, this wouldn't be possible, but our data could look like this:
iii ttt YYY Y0Y^{0}Y0 Y1Y^{1}Y1 δ\deltaδ
School 1 000 800800800 800800800 850850850 505050
School 2 000 900900900 900900900 870870870 −30-30−30
School 3 111 115011501150 110011001100 115011501150 505050
School 4 111 140014001400 130013001300 140014001400 100100100
  • In this case, we can calculate the population parameter ATEATEATE
  • Specifically, it would be the following:
ATE=850+870+1150+14004−800+900+1100+13004=1067−1025=42ATE = \frac{850+870+1150+1400}{4} - \frac{800+900+1100+1300}{4} = 1067 - 1025 = 42ATE=4850+870+1150+1400​−4800+900+1100+1300​=1067−1025=42
  • This indicates providing laptops to schools would increase SAT scores by 424242 points on average
  • Thus, we see there isn't any real significant difference between the control group and treatment group

Illustrating SDOSDOSDO with Test Scores

  • In reality, customers can be in either the control or treatment group

    • For example, school 111 can't actually participate in both groups at the same time
    • For school 1, Y1Y^{1}Y1 is a counterfactual
    • For school 4, Y0Y^{0}Y0 is his counterfactual
  • As a result, our data actually looks like the following:
iii ttt YYY Y0Y^{0}Y0 Y1Y^{1}Y1 δ\deltaδ
School 1 000 800800800 800800800 null null
School 2 000 900900900 900900900 null null
School 3 111 115011501150 null 115011501150 null
School 4 111 145014501450 null 145014501450 null
  • Notice, in almost all cases we can't calculate ATEATEATE
  • Instead, we must estimate ATEATEATE by calculating SDOSDOSDO
  • Specifically, SDOSDOSDO would be the following:
SDO=1150+14502−800+9002=1300−850=450SDO = \frac{1150+1450}{2} - \frac{800+900}{2} = 1300 - 850 = 450SDO=21150+1450​−2800+900​=1300−850=450
  • Notice, this indicates providing laptops to schools would increase SAT scores by 450 points on average
  • In this case, making an assumption about causality based on SDOSDOSDO would be a mistake
  • Again, SDOSDOSDO is an estimator, so this difference is due to selection bias

Motivating Selection Bias in Causality

  • Bias is what separates association from causation

  • Selection bias could exist if the treatment group contains schools with more resources

    • For example, maybe the treatment group contains private schools
    • And, maybe the control group are underfunded
  • Since bias exists, we can't draw any conclusions about causal effects using SDOSDOSDO, ATUATUATU, or ATTATTATT
  • If there wasn't any bias, we could see the treatment group has much better SAT scores compared to the control group
  • Specifically, we could see this by computing and comparing ATUATUATU and ATTATTATT
  • We can see ATUATUATU and ATTATTATT are the following:
ATT=100+502=75ATT = \frac{100+50}{2} = 75ATT=2100+50​=75 ATU=50−302=10ATU = \frac{50-30}{2} = 10ATU=250−30​=10
  • Notice, the ATEATEATE is just a weighted average of ATTATTATT and ATUATUATU
